newsitem.title: USA: NASA may rerun Columbia's curtailed mission.
newsitem.headline: NASA may rerun Columbia's curtailed mission.

text.p: The space shuttle Columbia had barely come to a halt after its mission was cut short on Tuesday before NASA began considering sending it back to space to complete some unfinished business.

Space agency officials said the shuttle could be turned around in near-record time to rerun its mission, aborted because of a malfunctioning power generator. Columbia and its crew could be ready to fly again as soon as July 2.
"We're going to try to give y'all an oil change and send you back," Kennedy Space Centre director Roy Bridges joked with shuttle commander Jim Halsell after Columbia's early homecoming.
"We are evaluating the possibility of re-flying as early as the first part of July," shuttle programme director Tommy Holloway said. "I expect that evaluation will take the rest of this week."
Columbia soared through wispy clouds on Tuesday and touched down at the Florida spaceport at 2:33 p.m. EDT (1833 GMT), less than four days after blasting off.
The planned 16-day science mission was cut short because one of the shuttle's three electricity-generating fuel cells was behaving unusually and could have sparked a fire or explosion.

The loss of the device did not affect the landing of the $2 billion shuttle, which can fly safely powered by two working generators. Some landing systems were activated later than usual to conserve power.
It was only the third time in 83 missions since the shuttle programme began in 1981 that NASA called a shuttle home early because of a mechanical breakdown.
A faulty fuel cell was to blame for cutting short NASA's second shuttle flight in November 1981, and a failed navigation device ended a 1991 mission prematurely.

There were signs of trouble with the $5 million fuel cell during Columbia's countdown, but it appeared to have returned to normal before Friday's blastoff. Engineers had seen similar pre-launch readings from other generators that did not develop problems in flight.
One such fuel cell on shuttle Atlantis was being replaced on Tuesday as precaution, Holloway said. Atlantis was scheduled to fly to the Russian space station Mir next month.
Columbia's astronauts left orbit with only a fraction of their $84 million research programme accomplished.
"We're just sorry we're having to close up shop early," mission control's Marc Garneau told the crew as they shut down Columbia's laboratory early on Tuesday.

Columbia's crew of seven had been living in near-darkness since the troublesome power generator was shut down on Sunday, working with flashlights. All non-essential equipment including most of the lighting was turned off to conserve power for scientific experiments.
The astronauts were to have performed 33 major experiments, including several to study the behaviour of fire in space.
